text: Job Continues to Argue His Case with God
“A human being born of a woman
\add is\add* short of days and full of troubles.\f + \fr 14:1 \ft Literally “trouble” \f*
Like a flower he comes up, and he withers away;
and he flees like a\f + \fr 14:2 \ft Or “the” \f* shadow, but\f + \fr 14:2 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* he does not last.
Even on such a one you fix your eyes,
and you bring me into judgment with you.
“Who can bring a clean \add thing\add* from an unclean \add thing\add*?
No one!\f + \fr 14:4 \ft Or “Not one” \f*
If his days \add are\add* determined, the number of his months \add is\add* with you;
you have appointed his boundaries, and he cannot cross \add them\add*.
Look away from him, and let him desist
until he enjoys his days like a laborer.
“Indeed, there is hope for a tree:
if it is cut down, then\f + \fr 14:7 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* it will sprout again,
and its new shoots will not cease;
though its root grows old in the earth,
and its stump dies in the dust,
at\f + \fr 14:9 \ft Hebrew “from” \f* the scent of water it will bud,
and it will put forth branches like a young plant.
“But\f + \fr 14:10 \ft Hebrew “And” \f* a man dies, and he dwindles away;
thus\f + \fr 14:10 \ft Hebrew “And” \f* a human being passes away, and where is he?\f + \fr 14:10 \ft Or “where is he \fq then \ft ?” \f*
\add As\add* water disappears from a lake,
and a river withers away and dries up,\f + \fr 14:11 \ft Or “it dries up” \f*
⸤so⸥\f + \fr 14:12 \ft Literally “and” \f* a man lies down, and he does not arise.
⸤Until the heavens are no more⸥,\f + \fr 14:12 \ft Literally “Until not heavens” \f* they will not awaken,
and they will not be roused out of their sleep.
“⸤O that⸥\f + \fr 14:13 \ft Literally “Who shall give” \f* you would conceal me in Sheol,
\add that\add* you would hide me ⸤until your wrath is past⸥,\f + \fr 14:13 \ft Literally “until the return of your nose” \f*
\add that\add* you would appoint a set time for me and remember me.
If a man dies, will he live \add again\add*?
All the days of my compulsory service I will wait,
until the coming of my relief.
You would call, and I myself\f + \fr 14:15 \ft Emphatic personal pronoun \f* would answer you;
you would long for the work of your hand.
For then\f + \fr 14:16 \ft Hebrew “now” \f* you would count my steps,
\add but\add* you would not keep watch over my sin.
My transgression would be sealed in a bag,
and you would cover over my guilt.
“But\f + \fr 14:18 \ft Or “And but” \f* a mountain falls; it crumbles away,
and a rock moves away from its place.
Water wears away stones;
its torrents wash away \add the\add* soil of \add the\add* earth;
so\f + \fr 14:19 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* you destroy the hope of human beings.
You overpower him forever, and he passes away;
\add you\add* change ⸤his countenance⸥,\f + \fr 14:20 \ft Literally “his faces” \f* ⸤then⸥\f + \fr 14:20 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* you send him away.
His children may \add come to\add* honor, but\f + \fr 14:21 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* he does not know \add it\add*;
or\f + \fr 14:21 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* they may become lowly, but\f + \fr 14:21 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* he does not realize it.\f + \fr 14:21 \ft Or “them” \f*
He feels only the pain of his own body,\f + \fr 14:22 \ft Hebrew “his body on him” \f*
and his inner self\f + \fr 14:22 \ft Or “soul” \f* mourns for him.”\f + \fr 14:22 \ft Or “for himself” \f*
